user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of producer_thread:
```c
static void *producer_thread(void *arg)
{
	(void)arg;
	metal_mutex_acquire(&lock);
	while (counter == COUNTER_MAX)
		metal_condition_wait(&nfull_condv, &lock);
	counter++;
	metal_condition_signal(&nempty_condv);
	metal_mutex_release(&lock);

	return NULL;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function producer_thread:
static unsigned int counter
...
#define COUNTER_MAX 10
...
METAL_MUTEX_DEFINE(lock)
...
static struct metal_condition nfull_condv = METAL_CONDITION_INIT
...
static struct metal_condition nempty_condv = METAL_CONDITION_INIT
...
int metal_condition_wait(struct metal_condition *cv,
				       metal_mutex_t *m)
{
	uintptr_t tmpmptr = 0, mptr = (uintptr_t)m;
	int v = 0;

	/* Check if the mutex has been acquired */
	if (!cv || !m || !metal_mutex_is_acquired(m))
		return -EINVAL;

	if (!atomic_compare_exchange_strong(&cv->mptr, &tmpmptr, mptr)) {
		if (tmpmptr != mptr)
			return -EINVAL;
	}

	v = atomic_load(&cv->wakeups);
	atomic_fetch_add(&cv->waiters, 1);

	/* Release the mutex before sleeping. */
	metal_mutex_release(m);
	syscall(SYS_futex, &cv->wakeups, FUTEX_WAIT, v, NULL, NULL, 0);
	atomic_fetch_sub(&cv->waiters, 1);
	/* Acquire the mutex after it's waken up. */
	metal_mutex_acquire(m);

	return 0;
}
...
int main(void)
{
	int status;

	status = metal_tests_run(NULL);

	return status;
}
...
static void *mutex_thread(void *arg)
{
	metal_mutex_t *l = arg;
	int i;

	for (i = 0; i < mutex_test_count; i++) {
		metal_mutex_acquire(l);
		usleep(1);
		metal_mutex_release(l);
	}

	return NULL;
}
...
static void *consumer_thread(void *arg)
{
	(void)arg;
	metal_mutex_acquire(&lock);
	while (!counter)
		metal_condition_wait(&nempty_condv, &lock);
	counter--;
	metal_condition_signal(&nfull_condv);
	metal_mutex_release(&lock);

	return NULL;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I flagged all places in the provided code that can affect reachability (thread entry functions, the condition-wait implementation with its early-return/error paths, the counter/COUTNER_MAX definitions and the mutex/condition initializations, plus main and the mutex thread). These fragments are the only locations in the supplied code where execution may be prevented from reaching subsequent statements (blocking waits, early returns on error, or shared-state conditions that can remain true/false across threads). Other smaller statements and expressions in the snippets (local variable declarations, simple arithmetic, atomic load/fetch calls, usleep, the return statements at the ends of functions, etc.) are straightforward and do not themselves constitute statically unreachable code, so they were not separately reported. If additional code (macros or omitted sections) is present elsewhere in the project, those should be reviewed as well, but based on the supplied code these are the relevant fragments to investigate for potential unreachable-code violations of MISRA C Rule 2.1.
